WRITING.TEXT: For Russian history - Land of the Firebird by Suzanne Massie. It's from like 1000 CE to 1917.
Grand theft book. Did you somehow manage to check out a Gutenberg Bible? Holy over-reaction.

I'd personally say it's more accountability than a fine. If you lose the book, you should replace it. To me that seems a very different thing than not being able to return it by 4pm on a Thursday and having to pay. Or a kid forgetting it at school over the weekend, the other parents house for a week or two and then having to pay the cost of the book or more even when the book is eventually given back.

Pretty much. Also a great way to send your parents through the roof. Then heaven forbid the book has been lost and you get to pay the list price of the book plus like a convenience fee kind of thing on top of the fine.
My old library, if the book got lost they were Thrilled if you ordered another copy yourself and brought it in rather than paying out. New library, nope, they won't accept that. If I were prone to having overdue books or losing them, I'd rather buy it and risk just the loss of the initial pay out rather than like 2x-4x the list price of the book.

They aren't wrong. The last town I lived in - no fines for printed material ever. If you were overdue, they would email you and if you didn't return the book within like 2 months, you'd need to pay or replace the copy.
The town we're in now - it's something to the tune of a dollar a day. I can't imagine that if you're a working parent that has all the usual kid stuff to worry about on top of the regular household stuff that you're really going to want to risk the possible fines.
I only have anecdotal evidence, but based on the number of people I've seen with kids at each library, the one that doesn't fine has a lot more patrons with kids checking out material.
Now that sounds like the start of a good novel...

That makes me so incredibly sad... The Martian is such a great book. It should just be incentive to the big publishers to search more diligently for the good material that's out there.
Thanks for the insight - I had no idea that the publishers did that kind of cycle.

There are certainly books I've read just to be able to talk about them, kind of like movies I've watched just because my group had an interest. But I wonder how big of an impact that might have on the work's overall sales. I guess it would have to be introduced to the "right" group or person to see huge ripples, but I do wonder.

I'm curious about the buying aspect from the industry too. Do the stores/the industry itself create the hype because they're hoping to create the next Harry Potter?
I do suspect that a great many people of skimming, reading the Wiki or otherwise sort of falsely crafting an opinion (or outright stealing...) so have something to say about it. But in that situation, would they offer it as a recommendation? I guess that probably depends on how far they want to take the charade...

And that's where the question comes from really. I've seen people really hate or feel totally indifferent toward books I've really liked.
But books like The Historian by Kostova, I tried so hard to even finish and I just couldn't and was surrounded by the raves about it. I still haven't figured that one out. Some of it, I'm sure, comes down to taste. I enjoy the story of Lord of the Rings, but I do not enjoy Tolkien's writing style. That one, totally accept is on me. I don't want to read him but I understand why other people adore his books. Some of them though, I get through, don't enjoy the way it's written, the story that's told, the characters and find the ending disappointing, unfulfilling, etc and just can't understand why people recommend it.

I worked in a bookstore for a long time and wish there were more customer that had done this. I spent time on those reviews darn it!
There were so many fiction books that came through that I heard all these great things about, read a 100 pages and just had to stop because I was so annoyed with the accolades heaped on it or just could not for the life of me get into it.

WRITING.TITLE: Do lies create best-sellers?
WRITING.TEXT:
I've seen several articles lately on how a huge portion of people lie about having read a book they really didn't. They've even created lists of the mostly commonly lied about books - http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/books-lied-reading-article-1.3108606
After having read a few books that made the best-sellers lists, were featured in magazines and raved about on social media that I didn't think lived up to the hype, I'm now wondering if some best-sellers are simply created because people want to appear better read than they are. If the right person recommends it will people buy it, never read it, and rave about it anyway? I know that we all bring our own perspectives to books and there will be a vast assortment of those loving and hating the same book, so have I simply missed the point of some these hits or has social media and celebrity made certain books over rated?

I'm hoping this is along the lines of what you're looking for...
S. (Ship of Theseus) by J.J. Abrams and Doug Dorst is... a book within a book with clues and a mystery on top of a mystery. It's truly amazing.
It's classified as YA and the story itself is definitely more for teenagers, but there is "Cathy's Book" by Sean Stewart. There's a "evidence pack" (in the paperback it's all printed in the back as opposed to being separate physical pieces in the original publishing) that has phone numbers, websites, etc that you can call or look at to help fill in more of the story. There are 2 sequels to this.

As someone said - used bookstores. Then thrift shops (Goodwill, Salvation Army, independent charity shops). Many libraries have used book stores attached to them. If you're in the US or Canada there's booksalefinder.com that can give you a better idea of when the big area/library/charity book sales are.
Coupons, bargain books, clearance at big box stores. Checking used listings on Amazon, checking ebay.
If you have an e-reader, check out bookbub.com - they'll at least give you notification of e-books that are on sale or free. If you aren't branded with an e-reader but have a tablet, download the various apps (nook, kindle, etc). Many library systems also have the ability to borrow ebooks.
Sign up at sites that do giveaways or ARCs in exchange for reviews.

I'm not sure what counts as a less well known winner but I recommend Number the Stars, Jacob have I loved, The Westing Game, Island of the Blue Dolphins, The witch of blackbird pond, Cassie Woodlawn, and I absolutely loved this year's winner - The Girl who drank the moon.

Maybe the challenge is to actually read the books, not find them?
Edit - Though having a book scavenger hunt could be very entertaining....

Pope Joan by Donna Woodfolk Cross. I appreciated that there was a section included at the end with the evidence (circumstantial or otherwise) there is supporting the existence of a female pope despite the formal denials from the Catholic Church.

Sorcery and Cecelia by Patricia Wrede is a book of written in letters (fictions/fantasy)
A Week in Winter by Maeve Binchy
Chew on This : Everything you don't want to know about Fast Food
Career advice I'd have think about...
A Walk in the Woods by Bill Bryson
Lolita. Anne of Green Gables. Sabriel. The Unexpected Mrs. Polifax.
Murder on Monday. Tuesdays with Morrie. Drowned Wednesday. Thursday Next (also the name of the main character). Friday Night Lights. Saturday by Ian McEwan. The Sunday Philosophy Club.
I will have to look that one up. I saw the IMAX film that they released but there's very little detail about the incident in that so I am interested to read a more unbiased accounting. Thanks.

I had actually seen "Left for Dead" not too long before this post on Amazon and started thinking about the perspective he gave. He was extremely harsh about Sandy Pittman and not very gentle about a few of the other climbers as well. Not yet having read any of the other accounts, I wasn't sure if that was because the other climbers were truly that inexperienced and that much of a liability that day or if Krakauer's own ego kept him from being truly objective. Maybe the trauma and the grief played in.
It seems like the majority of the other survivors have put out their own books on the events of that excursion, so I will have to start working my way through them.

There's the Merchant Princes series by Charles Stross - there's a lot of court politicking, different branches of families trying to gain power (sci-fi/fantasy)
There's Team of Rivals by Doris Goodwin about Abraham Lincoln which is about how he got elected and then how he was able to unite people enough that were so seriously at odds to be able to actually run the country and win a war.
Hissing Cousins by Marc Peyser is about the rivalry between Eleanor Roosevelt (wife of FDR) and Alice Roosevelt Longworth (daughter of Teddy Roosevelt)
There is a fantasy series, The Keltiad by Patricia Kennealy(-Morrison) that has some of all of that... There are 3 galactic empires basically that have been at odds with each other for generations. If you start with The Silver Branch you can get the bonus of the friends eventually hating each other too.

His Dark Materials by Phillip Pullman has a lot to talk about (The Golden Compass).
Serephina by Rachel Hartman
Uglies (followed by Pretties and Specials) by Scott Westerfeld can certainly generate a lot of conversation too...

Everything I've read by Krakauer has been riveting, I enjoyed Into Thin Air immensely.
I have wondered, after reading the foreword or afterward in the version I read, if others have read this as well as the accounts written by others from this expedition and how well the accounts match up. He spends so much time going into detail about the oxygen deprivation, the sleep deprivation and how altered he feels his state of mind was, so I just wonder if the other perspectives are close or completely different.

Because the two series you listed are classified for younger readers, along the same lines there is...
Septimus Heap by Angie Sage
Rick Riordan - he has several series
The Inheritence Cycle - Christopher Paolini
Fablehaven - Brandon Mull
If you want something targeted slightly older I'd suggest trying His Dark Materials - Phillip Pullman
The Enchanted Forest Chronicles - Patricia Wrede
The Old Kingdom series by Garth Nix (Sabriel)
If you'd like older than that, check out Mercedes Lackey, Jasper Fforde, or Rob Thurman.

Cassandra Clare's books are along that line - The Infernal Devices and the Mortal Instruments books, though as a disclaimer, those are YA.
Charlaine Harris's Sookie Stackhouse series (the one True Blood is based on) is in that concept - vampires came out to the world once a company figured out how to manufacture synthetic blood so the vampires don't Have to feed on humans. Also contains were-everything, fairies etc.
You also might like the Cal Leandros books by Rob Thurman (Nightlife is the first one) or The Dresden Files by Jim Butcher.

Animal Farm is so different than 1984 it's hard to do a better/worse comparison. Animal Farm has a lot of the same kinds of messages but the humor he uses to communicate them, the allegory, while not subtle, made it a little easier for me to be emotionally removed from the story. It's still pretty disturbing but it comes off as somewhat less menacing than 1984, at least to me.

They're pretty varied - sci-fi, biography and a murder mystery so I don't have that problem with this set. That has happened on occasion and then I have to go back and start one of them all over again.
Fuzzy Nation by John Scalzi, Shooting Victoria by Paul Murphy and Real Murders by Charlaine Harris. I have a hard time sticking with one start to finish so I tend to read a few at the same time.

It is one of my very favorite books. I feel that books are like friends - you have a few that are always there waiting to help you if you're having a bad day and P P is one of those for me. Glad you're enjoying it!

This makes me think of American Gods by Neil Gaiman...
I'd also recommend A Game of Universe by Eric Nylund - it's out of print in hard copy but it's available on the Kindle at least.
If you don't mind books created for a younger crowd, Rick Riordan's The Kane Chronicles might fit the bill.

My personal favorite? Hercule Poirot series by Agatha Christie. I'm also a fan of Martha Grimes and Anne Perry.
Perhaps a little closer to Baldacci - Jeffery Deaver, Lee Child, Vince Flynn.
Another great book that isn't a detective story exactly but is a great mystery if The Thirteenth Tale by Diane Setterfield.
Roberto Bolao is a great author.

Because of loving Anne, I'd suggest LM Montgomery's Emily of New Moon series if you haven't gotten there.
You might also want to look at T. H. White's The Once and Future King
Any of Jane Austen's novels
Louisa May Alcott
To Kill a Mockingbird - Harper Lee
If you are willing to move away from classics... take a look Maeve Binchy - they're sort of Anne-esque but intended for adults and set in modern day and I don't know how you feel about going in that direction.
I highly suggest Alice in Quantumland by Robert Gilmore.

This is not a problem. I have a program called ReaderWare that's more or less the same thing except you can use a barcode scanner, it will auto-populate from the websites of your choice (Amazon, etc). It even has a lending library type option if you happen to allow people to borrow books from you.

Princess by Jean Sasson - biography of a Saudi Arabian princess I found extremely interesting.
Rosemary by Kate Clifford Larson did a good job of staying engaging through the whole work - it's about JFK's younger, disabled sister.
In the Garden of Beasts (Erik Larson) I found fascinating - about an American ambassador posted to Hitler's Berlin.
Sleeping with the Enemy (Hal Vaughan) is about Coco Chanel, specifically her time in Paris during WW2 and her affair with a Nazi officer.
Unorthodox (Deborah Feldman) is an autobiography of a woman who left her Jewish orthodox community and an abusive marriage.
And if you like animal stories... Dewey by Vicki Myron is about a cat that was adopted by a library after he was abandoned.
There is some romance in it. It's not the main focus of the series by any means and it takes a bit to get started in the first book, but it is there.

His Fair Assassins by Robin LaFevers
The Uglies series by Scott Westerfeld
The Lunar Chronicles by Melissa Meyer
The Merchant Princes series by Charles Stross - excellent adult female protag, not paranormal - its a dimension jumping fantasy, modern day.
The Keltiad by Patricia Kennealy (or Kennealy-Morrison depending on the book and edition). I prefer the Aeron series, but the others are also engaging.
There is a series by Susan Wittig Albert - The Cottage Tales of Beatrix Potter. The story is not told completely by the animals, but they do play a large role in the stories.

Robin Hobb's Assassin's Apprentice might be up that alley.
The Temeraire series by Naomi Novik if you don't mind some dragons and alternate history.
If you like Ranger's Apprentice and haven't tried Rick Riordan I would suggest him. All of his series are pretty fun and engaging.

To Kill a Mockingbird was one of my favorites and I loved it in high school. I actually liked a great many of the books we were required to read, but I was the oddity that had read most of them before we were told they were required. Jane Austen, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Hemingway, Dumas, Animal Farm, Dracula and Frankenstein...
I did not love Turn of the Screw and I still hate having to read plays.
Anything by Sarah Addison Allen.

Have you ever tried Christopher Moore?
Also would suggest Douglas Adams.
Slightly further afield but you might like to try Martha Grimes' Richard Jury mysteries. Jury ends up with Melrose Plant and some very British humor accompanies the investigations.

The Ocean at the End of the Lane by Neil Gaiman.
I'd also recommend Odd Thomas. He's a 20-ish character but pretty much everyone is oblivious to the boogeymen he sees.

The Parasol Protectorate by Gail Carringer. - Werewolves, vampires, ghosts and the soulless.
The Sookie Stackhouse books by Charlene Harris (The books True Blood is based on) have quite a lot of were side characters along with the vampires.

The Old Kingdom series by Garth Nix (I'd start with Sabriel)
His Dark Materials by Philip Pullman - I recommend because you like HP, they are written for a somewhat younger crowd but they're still engaging.
Odd Thomas by Dean Koontz - often classified as horror but they're really much more fantasy.

I find that so many of the classics deal with the human condition, at least as it was in the their time period. Often references classics that I would recommend:
Jane Austen - Pride and Prejudice; Sense and Sensibility; Mansfield Park; Emma; Persuasion - All dealing with various aspects of the human condition - usually family relationships, constraints of society - Mansfield Park addresses a fair amount of morality and views on slavery.
The Bronte sisters - Wuthering Heights as someone else recommended, Jane Eyre
To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee - life in a small southern town and how being different impacts one's life, how the lottery of birth can dictate your circumstances
I, Robot by Issac Asimov - Fantasy/AI/the morality and ethics of creating AI and how "laws" can be bent or broken based on perspective
The Giver by Lois Lowry
Brave New World by Aldous Huxley - Both this and the Giver are dystopian society books with very interesting perspectives on what affects human behavior and thought and how it can be controlled.
Not so much classics exactly as those I've found interesting...
In the Garden of Beasts by Erik Larson - historical about the US ambassador that was posted to Hitler's Berlin with his family - I would also recommend his others - The Devil in the White City, Thunderstruck, etc - they're histories that are just extremely interesting.
Gun, germs and Steel by Jared Diamond - a fascinating look at the development of the modern world
The Abhoreson Series by Garth Nix - fantasy series
Ender's Game by Orson Scott Card - debatable that this is a classic in sci-fi but certainly addresses what it means to be human
Leaving the Saints by Martha Beck.

The Twentieth Wife and the sequels by Indu Sundaresan. These are historical fiction set in India.
I also have really enjoyed the non-fiction by Jean Sasson - Princess and it's 4 (I think?) sequels. They're about a princess from the Saudi Arabian royal family.
I suggest The Little Paris Bookshop by Nina George. It's very relevant to healing following the loss of a relationship.
The Weird Sisters by Eleanor Brown

If you like historical stuff at all, Victoria Thompson's Gaslight Mystery Series is pretty good. The individual mysteries in each book are decently set up and the whole series has a great arc following the main character, exploring her past, her relationships, etc.
There's also a genre of mysteries called "cozy" in which I often find the mystery itself is really more of a window dressing for the main character just living their life. Ann Purser has a series Lois Meade that's kind fun. Charlene Harris has the Aurora Teagarden series as well.
If you like paranormal stuff at all, I'd suggest A Discovery of Witches by Deborah Harkness, though I think that's usually categorized as fiction rather than mystery.

The OddThomas series (Dean Koontz) read by David Aaron Baker. The books are from the first person and Baker just does an amazing job of making Odd sound real, communicating the emotion through the stories and giving enough of a different voice to the other characters I had no confusion as to who was speaking.
